title: Managing Ocular Trauma
author: Bhavin Patel
keyPoints: Open globe injury is a sight threatening emergency
Ocular trauma is classified by the Birmingham Eye Trauma Terminology System (BETTS)
Comprehensive documentation and explanation of risks whilst consenting patients avoids medicolegal issues
redFlags: Open globe injury signs (peaked pupil, soft eye, uveal prolapse)

q1.text: What was the mechanism of injury?

q2.text: Are there signs of open globe injury (peaked pupil, soft eye, uveal prolapse, positive Seidel's test)?

q3.text: Check for anterior segment signs: hyphema, iridodialysis, lens dislocation?

q4.text: Was the patient wearing safety goggles? Any high-velocity metal fragments?

answers.text: No safety equipment - high risk IOFB

q5.text: What is the visual acuity and pupil response?

q6.text: Any posterior segment involvement (vitreous hemorrhage, retinal detachment)?

q7.text: Any signs of orbital involvement (proptosis, reduced eye movements, orbital fracture)?

open_globe.text: URGENT OPEN GLOBE: NBM, bed rest, eye shield. Inform consultant immediately. IV access, FBC/U&E. Consent for GA primary repair. IV antibiotics (vancomycin 1g 12 hourly + ceftazidime 1g 8 hourly). Analgesia and antiemetics. Tetanus prophylaxis if indicated.

iofb_risk.text: HIGH RISK IOFB: Non-contrast CT orbit immediately. Look for metallic foreign body. If IOFB confirmed, treat as open globe. Urgent ophthalmology referral.

anterior_trauma.text: ANTERIOR SEGMENT TRAUMA: Detailed slit lamp examination. Manage hyphema with head elevation, cycloplegics. Monitor IOP. Ophthalmology referral within 24 hours.

posterior_trauma.text: POSTERIOR SEGMENT TRAUMA: Urgent vitreoretinal referral. B-scan ultrasound if view obscured. Consider commotio retinae, choroidal rupture, retinal detachment.

orbital_trauma.text: ORBITAL TRAUMA: CT orbits with coronal views. Check for orbital fractures, muscle entrapment. Urgent ophthalmology and maxillofacial referral if indicated.

globe_assessment.text: CLOSED GLOBE INJURY: Thorough examination for occult rupture. Monitor closely. Ophthalmology review. Document thoroughly for medicolegal purposes.

minor_trauma.text: MINOR TRAUMA: Superficial injury. Topical antibiotic if corneal abrasion. Safety advice. Routine follow-up if symptoms persist.
